titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Andrew W. Tanner Photographs, 1894-1909
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Michelle Sweetser, April 2003
Polly Reynolds, June 2005. Revised December 2013

did.abstract: Andrew Tanner was photographer, born in Missouri, who traveled about the United States. He lived for a time in Ann Arbor, Michigan and on Coryell Island (part of the Les Cheneaux Islands) in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. The collection consists of glass plate negatives of images taken while in different parts of the United States and Mexico.

physdesc.physfacet: including 280 glass plate negatives and 2 videotapes

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received from Betsy Kausch (donor no. 9198) in July and November 2002, February 2005, and May 2013.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Andrew W. Tanner Photographs, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Little is known about Andrew Wineland Tanner, the photographer who created the images in this collection. He was born ca. 1856 in Missouri, according to the 1930 Federal Census. Tanner married Ria Waite at some point in the 1870s, and the couple had at least one child, Volney, who was born ca. 1882. Tanner married Ella Wagner in 1925 (according to a memoir in Ripples from the Breezes, edited by Philip Pittman, p. 97), and the couple lived in Ann Arbor, Michigan at the time of the 1930 census.

It is unknown what allowed Tanner to travel around the country taking these photographs, although it appears likely that he and his brothers -- Charles and James -- were co-owners of a merchandising chain called Tanner Bros. General Stores. (See The National Cyclopaedia of American Biography entry for Allen Barnett Tanner, pictured in this collection, vol. 44, 1961-1964, pp. 415-416.)

Andrew's brother Charles purchased land on Coryell Island (part of Les Cheneaux) in 1897 (the sale was finalized in September 1897, according to the Mackinac Co. Letter Book, 1895-1910 held at this library), and the two built homes there at some point thereafter. Ripples from the Breezes notes that Andrew and Charles Tanner by 1905 "had completed one of the most individualistic, complete, and systematic cottage settlements in Les Cheneaux" (p. 28) with a "little Dutch wind-mill at the shore line, which housed their water system" (p. 28), and these cottages are well-documented in the images in the collection.

Tanner's land on Les Cheneaux was purchased by S.P. Upham sometime in the late 1930s or early 1940s (Ripples from the Breezes, p. 374), and later by Jack Kausch, who came into possession of the photograph collection.

scopecontent.p: The Andrew Tanner Photograph Collection includes glass plate negatives from his travels across the United State and in Mexico in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Images in the collection demonstrate in a vivid way life in the United States, the natural environment, and the photographic processes of the time. The plates are in excellent condition and images are of very good quality. Tanner's original plate numbers are indicated on the slides, and where known, are indicated on the sleeves containing the plates; some plates were also assigned numbers by their intermediate owner, Jack Kausch, and, where known, these are also indicated on the envelopes. The images in the collection (14 boxes) date from 1894 to 1909, and are organized into three series: 5x7 Plates, 1894-1909 (13 boxes), 8x10 Plates, ca. 1900 (1 linear foot), and Miscellaneous (1 linear foot).

The 5x7 Plates, 1894-1909 Series includes approximately 230 plates. Of particular interest and depth are the plates relating to the Garden of the Gods (Colorado), St. Louis, Mackinac Island and Les Cheneaux, as well as Tanner family portraits.

scopecontent.p: The 8x10 Plates, ca. 1900 Series contains approximately 50 plates, largely documenting life on Mackinac Island and Les Cheneaux. These plates do not duplicate the plates in the 5x7 series.

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous Series (1 linear foot) includes some biographical information, inventories of Tanner's photographs made by Jack Kausch, Tanner's film negatives, most of unknown locations and dates, copy negatives, diapositives, and prints made by Kausch from Tanner's negatives, and two videos featuring some of Tanner's photographs, both of which were created by Kausch. These videos, both short, provide an excellent visual introduction to Tanner's photographic work.

did.unittitle: Andrew Wineland Tanner: A Sense of History. Photographs of the late 19th and Early 20th Century.
